{{Cite check|date=July 2009}} {{Politics}} The '''executive''' arm/tier is the part of [[government]] that has sole [[authority]] and [[Moral responsibility|responsibility]] for the daily administration of the [[state (polity)|state]].<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Executive+Branch&fromAsk=true Executive Branch], www.dictionary.reference.com</ref> The executive branch executes the law. The division of power into separate branches of government is central to the idea of the [[separation of powers]].<ref>[http://www.reference.com/browse/separation%20of%20powers ... central to the idea of Separation of Powers], www.reference.com</ref>
In many countries, the term "government" connotes only the executive branch. However, this usage fails to differentiate between [[Despotism|despotic]] and [[democracy|democratic]] forms of government. In [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] systems, such as a [[dictatorship]] or [[absolute monarchy]], where the different powers of government are assumed by one person or small [[oligarchy]], the executive branch ceases to exist since there is no other branch with which to share separate but equal governmental powers.
The separation of powers system is designed to distribute [[authority]] away from the executive branch—an attempt to preserve [[individual liberty]] in response to tyrannical leadership throughout history.<ref>[http://www.constitution.org/fed/federa51.htm ... an attempt to preserve individual liberty], The Federalist Papers #51</ref> The executive officer is not supposed to make laws (the role of the [[legislature]]) or interpret them (the role of the [[judiciary]]). The role of the executive is to enforce the law as written by the legislature and interpreted by the judicial system.
==Responsibility== The top leadership roles of the executive branch may include:
*[[head of state]]—often the ''[[de jure]]'' leader, the chief public representative and living symbol of national unity. **[[head of government]]—often the ''[[de facto]]'' leader, overseeing the administration of all affairs of state and enforcing the law. ***[[defence minister]]—overseeing the [[armed forces]], managing and determining military policy. ***[[finance minister]]—overseeing the treasury and [[national budget]], managing and determining [[fiscal policy]]. ***[[foreign minister]]—overseeing the [[diplomatic service]], managing and determining [[foreign policy]].
In a [[presidential system]] the leader of the executive branch is at once the ''head of state and head of government''. In a [[parliamentary system]], a [[cabinet (government)|cabinet]] [[minister (government)|minister]] [[vote of no confidence|responsible to the]] [[legislature]] is the head of government, while the head of state is a largely ceremonial monarch or president.
